text: the Syrian civil war began in 2011 four
long years of conflict and more than
200,000 people killed it's estimated
four million people have fled the
country mostly into Turkey Lebanon and
Jordan so why now
the great migration to Europe there are
several factors combined together to
cause this huge wave of migration that's
being described by some as the biggest
wave of people movement since World War
two
the push factors are that the refugee
camps in the neighboring countries are
becoming oversaturated there is no jobs
there is no prospects of having a normal
life in these areas and people sees that
this temporary situation they cannot go
back to their countries and they're
seeing people making this trip
successfully the big game changer came
last month when Angela Merkel the German
Chancellor pledged that Syrians who
managed to reach Germany regardless of
how they got there could have their
asylum claims assessed there that
upended EU immigration rules which state
very clearly that refugees have to have
their claims assessed in the country in
the European country they first stepped
foot in another important factor is the
momentum affect people in Syria seeing
so many of their friends and relatives
reached Germany and be welcomed with
open arms and then there's the political
dimension as well there are many people
in Syria who just do not believe that
there will be a political solution to
this crisis this war this civil war that
has been raging for so long and they
believe they're living in a country
that's in a perpetual state of war the
numbers are
impressive for some they are frightening
but now is not a time to take flight it
is a time for both determined concerted
action by the European Union by its
member states and by its institutions
